intro: Cogswellia eastwoodiae, commonly known as the Eastwood's cactus, is a rare and unique species native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its spiny, cylindrical stems that store water, allowing it to survive in harsh, dry environments. The plant produces small, yellow flowers during the rainy season, adding a striking contrast to its rugged appearance. Its slow growth rate and limited distribution make it a highly sought-after specimen among botanists and collectors. Due to habitat loss and over-collection, it is also classified as endangered, highlighting the need for conservation efforts.
